title: So giving up CS to teammates can actually cost you an S rank - wow...
body:
I just played a game where I got quite fed really early as Ahri mid, but the enemy top and bot lanes were doing really well so it was a close game.

I was CS'ing fine/great for the first ~15-20min of the game, but I knew I'd hit full build early that game. I did indeed finish the game (with a win) at full build + sorc elixers and gold to spare.

I ended the game with a great score and was expecting an S+. Now, before all the haters start downvoting me, I ALREADY HAVE MASTERY 7 ON AHRI - I really don't care that I only got an S-.

That's what happened though. I carried the hell out of the game. Had by far the most damage (58k for me, the enemy ADC had 46k, my ADC and the enemy top each had 34k). Had about 90% kill participation, and about 50% of the total kills. 

And since I knew I was going to be full build, I told top and adc to take all the farm. I purposely hit the wave low and didn't last hit it so they could get farm (except when we needed to push).

My top laner finished with 100 more CS than me. He got an S. I got an S-. Despite me being 22/5/19 (41 kill participation of 46 total kills) and him being 5/3/15 (under 50% kill participation). Despite me having more than 2k more total gold than him. Despite the CS disparity being intentional because I didn't need any more gold.

I get WHY it happened - my CS was garbage at the end of the game. For about the last 20min I didn't do a last hit aside from getting blue buff. Seriously though, it was THE RIGHT MOVE that game. My top and ADC each finished the game with 17K gold. That'd have been about 14-15K if I had kept last hitting since I could insta-clear waves with Q-W (I'm also implicitly including gold they got from having the earlier gold and being able to get kills in fights I would have had to get the kills in otherwise). That's a full item on each of my two main ancillary carries, because I purposely gave them CS I didn't need. 

I had the entire focus of the enemy team all game. I took every ultimate they could throw at me, every summoner, and still survived the huge majority of fights (and got 2-3 kills out of the deal each time). I caught the enemy champions repeatedly with vision from my wards and ult'ing over walls to charm them and 100-0 them. I focused objectives all game long.  I went on a 13-kill streak. I had the presence of mind to give up most kills late game without allies dying because I knew I didn't need the gold but I needed fed allies. The game was the definition of a carry. 

I think games like this prove the mastery system really has no clue what it's doing. It can't detect when missing CS is a good move. How could it? Why wouldn't you want more gold? Oh, because your ally needs it more? Irrelevant...? 

As I said earlier, I don't care that I didn't get an S+. I already have Mastery 7 on Ahri, it makes no difference. I was just shocked. I mean, I looked afterwards and it was pretty obvious why, but at first I was really shocked. Like I said when this system first came out, it's going to encourage suboptimal play. People told me I was full of it - that if you play well you'll get an S+. No, stealing kills and getting as much gold on yourself as possible is how you get an S+ but not always how you win games.

That's what he's saying. And he's probably right. The point is that the system is really subpar. It isn't a good evaluator of skill/mastery, but instead merely attempts to quickly give players a rough idea.

It definitely does not take in to account the matchup you're in, enemy builds (e.g. you do well early so they all build resistances against you, letting your allies demolition them later but you're the one who did well, they get the mastery credit for damage to champions), only accounts for map presence to a limited extent (i.e. a jungler having lane presence is valued, but a laner getting camped for isn't adjusted downwards), etc...

I don't think KDA actually matters much at all though. I've had games where I went 3/5/8 and got a flat S despite being hard carried.

That's the issue with a general system applied across everything. It can't factor in specific circumstances, like you giving up farm to the other laners on your team because you don't need the gold, but they could use it.

While getting a similar score with 350cs at 32 minutes gave me an S-.

There probably is some game length criterion with mastery, since not only does ending a game faster sorta mean you did better but also champions are just better/worse at different times in the game. You got that Jinx S+ because you ended a game really quickly on a late-game champion.

Known category variables that Riot has released at some point or another: Champion, position, time. Champion/position combinations each have their own "bucket". Other variables (which are to date unconfirmed) are averaged with time ("averaged how" is unconfirmed).  So the expectation of a 10 minute game is different from a 30 minute game.
You performance is then compared to the average of all games in that "bucket" to determine a score.

Yeah, CS has an unnecessary weight towards getting an S+.  Back when I was trying to get my Rank 7 for Quinn,  I was focusing more on winning than padding my CS.  If I saw an opportunity to gank another lane and take an objective,  I would do that.  Pushing objectives and ending ASAP. that was my play style and it worked fine. 

 But winning games wasn't getting me my Rank 7.   I had to unnecessarily draw out the game so I could get 200+ CS, even though my team could have ended 5 minutes earlier.  after doing that the S+'s started rolling in and I got it in no time.

I get why such a system that just checks raw stats is in place.  But it just creates a checklist of things to do, and takes away from focusing on winning.

The mastery system consists of partial luck sometimes. As Support Healers it's a bit more accurate imo, but even there it's very disappointing when you're responsible for your Marksman's success and they get an S+ but you only get a B because something in the spaghetti code triggered that makes the system devalue you as a Support. Sometimes it's not even lack of wards that does it, and it's hard to understand why because the system doesn't give you feedback.

It's hard to improve when the system refuses to tell you how.

It doesn't have to.

The system should stop caring about CS if you have sufficient alternative gold that last hitting doesn't matter to you. CS should matter considerably more when behind or even. When significantly ahead, damage to champions (especially other lanes) and objectives (especially in other lanes) should matter a lot more and CS should matter a lot less. 

Also, even if you're ignoring all of that, there's the really easy answer: the system shouldn't care AT ALL about cs that you didn't last hit but an ALLY DID. If an ally gets the last hit, I didn't really miss it, did I? Even if I'm not intentionally trying to let him have it, if we're grouped in a lane as long as someone gets the last hit we're not wasting resources. It could easily keep track of CS allies have gotten while you were within ~1000 units and this could never happen.

There's a lot of interesting ideas in this comment!

But I think there is a mismatch between your ideas and the grading system basic principle. The grading system does only 1 thing: it compares you versus other players on the same champ/position. What you suggest, on the other hand, is rather generic, and not champion specific, and it considers each game in isolation, without using other games as a point of reference. To implement your suggestions, Riot would need to do a massive overhaul of the system.

Heres a link to the match: http://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/NA1/2338720226/219673520?tab=overview

The system judges you against other players on your champion. As such comparing your stats to another champion's stats would not 1-to-1 correspond for grades. Irelia (your top laner) normally gets more cs than you, but not by much (difference of 20). This means that she did better than her champions average than you did over your champions average. However she had half of her average deaths, while you had 1 less (both being 6). Now I have no idea if they track the raw kills, deaths, and assists or if they go off of the kda, but her dying less than you inflates it such that you aren't too far ahead of her in kda. The system also likely tracks objective participation and warding. For warding you were about even, both bought 2 pinks you with 2 more wards than him however he also destroyed more wards than you. I can't tell how much either of you participated for objectives however I suspect that Irelia used her TP to split push and help with objectives meaning she'd be on more objectives.

tl;dr I doubt that cs and kda are significantly different in weight, but there are other things that go into grading that Irelia probably did marginally better than you.
